column1: 문제 (자동으로 채워짐)
One goal is to turn readers into great observers of the poor design that (_____) so many of the problems of modern life.
(_____), I lay out the fundamental principles.
Good design is actually a lot harder to notice than poor design, (_____) because good designs fit our needs so well that the design is invisible, serving us without drawing attention to itself.
We can also design workarounds, ways of overcoming the (_____) of existing device.
I am delighted by the response, by the number of people who (_____) me about it.
We can also design workarounds, ways of overcoming the (_____) of existing devices.
Because we are all designers in the sense that all of us (_____) design our lives, our rooms, and the way we do things.
Bad design, on the other hand, screams out its (_____), making itself very noticeable
Home networks were (_____).
One goal is to turn readers into great observers of the (_____), of the poor design that gives rise to so many of the problems of modern life, especially of modern technology.
The First edition had a (_____) affordances.
Advanced discussions of the topics have been (_____) to maintain the compactness.
The book is (_____) an introduction.
Because although all the principles still applied, (_____) has been learned.
For example, the original book says nothing of what has (_____) be called "user experience".
I had to include (_____) from these experiences.
I tried to delete as much as I added to keep the total size (_____).
Who can predict what new companies will (_____), what existing companies will disappear, and what new technologies will (_____) in the next twenty-five years?
The one thing I can predict (_____) is that the principles of human psychology will remain the same.
… but although affordances make sense for interaction with physical objects, they are confusing when (_____) virtual ones.
(_____), I also wrote many articles and six books on related topics, some of which I thought important to include in the revision
Finally, one important component of the original edition was its (_____).

The one thing I can predict with certainty is that the principles of human psychology will remain the same,which means that the design principles here, based on psychology, on the nature of human (_____), emotion, action, and interaction with the world, will remain unchanged.

Signifiers are the most important addition to the chapter, a concept first introduced in my book Living with Complexity. The first edition had a focus upon (_____), but although (_____) make sense for interaction with physical objects, they are confusing when dealing with virtual ones.
(_____), the chapter is the same, and although all the photographs and drawings are new, the examples are pretty much the same.
Many have little of no (_____) design, so they have been eliminated from the revision.

column1: slip 과 mistake 의 차이점은??
column3:
slip: 이미 알고 있었고, 심지어 과거에 성공한 적이 있음에도 불구하고 한 실수
mistake: 지식적으로 몰라서 생기는 실수

column1: The chapter concludes with a quick discussion of the difficulties (_____) automation.
Everyone wants radical innovation, but the truth is, most radical innovations fail, and even when they do succeed, it can take multiple (_____) before they are accepted.
Few (_____) changes. Better examples.

The chapter concludes with a quick discussion of the difficulties posed by automation (from my book The Design of Future Things) and what I consider the best new approach to deal with design so as to either eliminate or minimize human error: (_____) engineering.

The chapter concludes with discussions of the trends to come, the future of books, the moral (_____)  of design, and the rise of small, do-it-yourself makers that are starting to revolutionize the way ideas are conceived and introduced into the marketplace: “the rise of the small,” I call it.
Be sure to include the quote marks: it (_____) facinating reading.
Imagine (_____) doors that din't work right.
It is one of my (____) art objects.
If I were placed in the cockpit of a modern jet airliner, my inability to perform well would (_____) surprise (_____) bother me.
The entrance was an (_____) row of six glass swinging doors, followed immediately by a second, identical row.
That’s a standard design: it helps reduce the airflow and (_____) maintain the indoor temperature of the building.
A friend told me of the time he got trapped in the doorway of a post office in a European city

column1: But why should I have trouble with doors and light switches, water (_____) and stoves?

These need not destroy the (_____).

Many products (_____) understanding simply because they have too many functions and controls.

decide on/upon (명사)와 decide to (동사)의 미세한 차이는 뭘까요
column3:
decide to 는 (시간적으로) 주어가 앞으로 무엇을 할건지가 중요한 방점이 찍히는 거고, decide on something 하면 그냥 시간적인 것, 행동적인 것은 상관 없고 그냥 여러 개의 선택지중에 하나를 선택한다는 뜻임.

I don’t care what you decide to do.
난 니가 뭘 하려고 하든 신경 안써.

How did you decide on your major?
전공은 어떻게 고르게 됐나요?

column1: If we get the rules wrong even slightly, the machine does what it is told, no matter how insensible and (____).
When done badly, the products are unusable, leading to great frustration and (_____).
This book covers everyday things, focusing on the (_____) between technology and people to ensure that the products actually fulfill human needs while being understandable and usable.

All artificial things are designed. Whether it is the layout of furniture in a room, the paths through a garden or forest, or the (_____) of an electronic device, some person or group of people had to decide upon the layout, operation, and mechanisms.
Because everything is designed, the number of areas is (_____), ranging from clothes and furniture to complex control rooms and bridges.

In the best of cases, the products should also be delightful and enjoyable, which means that not only must the requirements of engineering, manufacturing, and (_____) be satisfied, but attention must be paid to the entire experience, which means the aesthetics of form and the quality of interaction.
It is time to reverse the situation: to (___) the blame (___) the machines and their design.
It is the machine and its design that are (____).
In this accident, a rather simple mechanical failure was (_____).
Some come from (_____) restrictions by the designers, often to hold down cost.

This led to several days of difficulties and confusion, total destruction of the reactor, and a very close call to a severe radiation release, all of which brought the American nuclear power industry to a complete (_____).
But the committee I was on discovered that the plant’s control rooms were so poorly designed that error was (_____): design was at fault, not the operators.
When people fail to follow these (____), secret rules, and the machine does the wrong thing, ~~
It is not our duty to understand the(_____), meaningless dictates of machines.
The reasons for the (_____) in human-machine interaction are numerous.
People are (______) everyday things.
Everyday life sometimes seems like a never-ending (_____) confusion, continued errors, etc.
continual 과 continuous 의 차이점은 몰까요~?
column3:
continual : 가끔씩 멈추긴 함. 계속 여러번 반복적으로 된다는 뜻임.
continuous : 한 번 시작되면 영원히 지속되는 거임.

column1: In the multiple decades that (_____) since the first edition of this book was published, design has gotten better.
New technologies, new applications, and new methods of interaction are continually arising and evolving. New industries (_____).
And each new invention of technology or interaction technique requires experimentation and study before the principles of good design can be fully (_____) practice.
This understanding comes about primarily through observation, for people themselves are often (_____) their true needs, even (_____) the difficulties they are encountering.

Getting the specification of the thing to be defined is one of the most difficult parts of the design, so much so that the HCD principle is to avoid specifying the problem as long as possible but instead to (_____) repeated approximations.
Doing HCD within the rigid time, budget, and other (_____) of industry can be a challenge
